'''Nora Jane Struthers''' (born November 11, 1983) is an American singer-songwriter based in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] who is notable for her critically acclaimed [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and roots rock. ''Rolling Stone Country'' debuted a video for "Let Go" from Struthers' album ''Wake'' with an article in which Stephen L. Betts wrote that "the ever-widening scope of Nora Jane Struthers' musicality means that placing a neat, easy label on the genre she best represents is virtually impossible."<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Betts |first=Stephen L. |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/nora-jane-struthers-and-the-party-line-shatter-societal-pressure-in-let-go-video-20150114 |title=Watch Nora Jane Struthers and the Party Line's 'Let Go' Video |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=January 14, 2015 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> In a post for [[Amy Poehler]]'s blog ''Smart Girls'', Alexa Peters wrote that "Nora Jane is entirely and unequivocally herself, and wants to encourage you to do the same."<ref name="amysmartgirls1">{{cite web |author=Alexa Peters |url=http://amysmartgirls.com/2015/01/smartists-norah-jane-struthers/ |title=Smartists: Nora Jane Struthers | Smart Girls at the Party |publisher=Amysmartgirls.com |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20150201232436/http://amysmartgirls.com/2015/01/smartists-norah-jane-struthers/ |archivedate=February 1, 2015 }}</ref> [[National Public Radio (United States)]] described Struthers as "quietly brilliant" in article headlined "Country Music's Year of the Woman."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2013/06/06/188997881/country-musics-year-of-the-woman |title=Country Music's Year of the Woman : The Record |publisher=NPR |date=n.d.|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> Struthers' 2013 album ''Carnival,'' recorded with her touring band The Party Line, spent more than three months in the Top 20 of Americana Radio charts and peaked at No. 7.<ref name="engine2">{{cite web |url=http://www.engine145.com/sideshows-and-sequins-nora-jane-struthers-carnival |title=Sideshows and Sequins: Nora Jane Struthers' Carnival |publisher=Engine 145 |date=September 5, 2013 |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218215221/http://www.engine145.com/sideshows-and-sequins-nora-jane-struthers-carnival/ |archivedate=February 18, 2015 }}</ref> ''Carnival'' ranked 24th on the 2013 Americana Airplay Top 100 list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanamusic.org/americana-announces-2013-top-10-top-100-jason-isbells-southeastern-tops-chart|title=Americana announces 2013 Top 10/ Top 100; Jason Isbell's, Southeastern Tops chart!|publisher=Americana Music|accessdate=February 19, 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218182055/http://americanamusic.org/americana-announces-2013-top-10-top-100-jason-isbells-southeastern-tops-chart|archivedate=February 18, 2015}}</ref> In a review of ''Carnival'', the ''Tampa Bay Times'' wrote that Struthers' unique brand of "rich storytelling, repeat-worth melodies and a modern mashup of traditional, bluegrass folk, country and rock influences" sets her apart from many roots-inspired contemporaries.<ref name="tampabay1">{{cite web|url=https://www.tampabay.com/things-to-do/music/nora-jane-struthers-and-the-party-lines-carnival-is-an-americana-gem/2115516/ |title=Nora Jane Struthers and the Party Line's 'Carnival' is an Americana gem |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=n.d.|access-date=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

==Early life and education==
Struthers was born in [[Fairfax, Virginia]] six months before her family moved to [[Avon, Connecticut|Avon, Conn]]. When Struthers was four years old the family moved again to [[Ridgewood, New Jersey]]. She grew up singing and playing music with her father Alan Struthers, a bluegrass musician.<ref name="engine2"/> Struthers was named Nora by her parents after [[Nick and Nora Charles|Nora Charles]], a character in Dashiell Hammett's novel [[The Thin Man]], and Jane after English author [[Jane Austen]]. Her family called her Jane, but Nora stuck in school when that name was used for calling roll in kindergarten.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/biography/ |title=Biography |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=June 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

Struthers said as a little girl she would often watch out the front window for her father at the end of the day and greet him with a yodel and the two frequented bluegrass festivals and fiddler conventions along the East Coast as she got older.<ref name="engine2"/>

Struthers was diagnosed with dyslexia at the age of four, when a reading specialist told her parents that Nora Jane would never go to college.<ref name="amysmartgirls1"/> She ultimately proved the reading specialist wrong, however, studying English Education and Africana Studies at New York University's School of Education. After graduating in 2005, Struthers worked as a teacher at The Williamsburg Charter High School in [[Brooklyn]], New York until 2008.<ref name="huffingtonpost1">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-bialas/faces-of-telluride-part-3_b_877219.html |title=Faces of Telluride, Part 3: Nora Jane Struthers, Fresh Face | Michael Bialas |work=HuffPost |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

==Career==
Struthers played shows with her father under the name Dirt Road Sweetheart and the duo released an album titled ''I Heard The Bluebirds Sing'' on May 11, 2008. In 2008, Struthers gave up her job as a teacher and moved to Nashville to pursue a career as a full-time musician. She soon began touring with a band of rotating musicians she dubbed The Bootleggers and ultimately won the prestigious [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]] band contest in June 2010.<ref name="engine2"/>

Struthers released a self-titled debut solo album on July 10, 2010. ''Nora Jane Struthers'', produced by Brent Truitt, featured established musicians such as multi-instrumentalist Tim O'Brien and fiddler Stuart Duncan.<ref name="huffingtonpost1"/>

Struthers joined [[Americana music|Americana]] acoustic quintet [[Bearfoot (American band)|Bearfoot]] later in 2010 and the group released the album ''[[American Story (album)|American Story]]'' in 2011, which featured six songs written or co-written by Struthers. One of them, "Tell Me a Story," became a top-rated video on [[Country Music Television|CMT]].<ref name="huffingtonpost1"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eventseeker.com/artist/49984-nora-jane-struthers|title=Nora Jane Struthers – Artist Profile|date=n.d.|website=eventseeker.com|access-date=March 4, 2020}}</ref>

Struthers had written a collection of songs for a new solo album by 2012 and launched a Kickstarter campaign that raised $22,000 in less than four weeks to help fund it. She formed a touring band called The Party Line and released the 14-track ''Carnival'' on April 16, 2013, again produced by Truitt.<ref name="huffingtonpost1"/>

Struthers and The Party Line gave nearly 150 live performances across the U.S. in 2013. Struthers said she achieved a childhood dream by playing in the Saturday Night All Star Jam at the Grey Fox Bluegrass Festival in [[Oak Hill, New York]] that year.<ref>{{cite web |author=Paul Wallen |url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/nora-jane-struthers-banner-year |title=Nora Jane Struthers' Banner Year |publisher=The Bluegrass Situation |date=January 14, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219165254/http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/nora-jane-struthers-banner-year |archive-date=February 19, 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

Struthers and The Party Line released a six-song record titled ''Country EP No. 1'' in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/discography/country-ep-no-1/ |title=Country EP No. 1 |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=July 1, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> One of the tracks, a cover of [[The Everly Brothers]] classic "(Til) I Kissed You" was featured on a collection of Americana music called ''Native: Americana Spotlight'', released on September 9, 2014 on Tone Tree Music.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/native-americana-spotlight/id912894515 |title=iTunes Music – Native: Americana Spotlight by Various Artists |publisher=iTunes Store |date=September 9, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

Struthers and The Party Line have recorded a new full-length studio album called ''Wake'', featuring 11 original songs. ''Wake'' is slated to be released in February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/discography/wake/ |title=Wake |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=June 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

Dirt Road Sweetheart a father-daughter duo (Nora Jane and Alan Struthers) released a new album 'Rose of My Heart' on June 16, 2019 under the label of Blue Pig Music.

In February 2020, Nora announced her fifth studio album titled 'Bright Lights, Long Drives, First Words'.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/nora-jane-struthers-new-song-nice-to-be-back-home-new-album-915757/|title=Nora Jane Struthers Previews New Album With Contented 'Nice to Be Back Home'|date=November 21, 2019|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=March 4, 2020}}</ref>

==Reception==
Reception
Grammy Award-winning musician Tim O'Brien said "Old time music continues to reinvent itself in the able hands of young artists like Nora Jane Struthers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/press/ |title=Press Kit |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=November 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

Kim Ruehl wrote for [[NPR Music]] that Struthers has a "voice as sweet as honeysuckle."<ref>{{cite web|last=Ruehl |first=Kim |url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/176172165/nora-jane-struthers-the-party-line-hootenanny-anyone |title=Nora Jane Struthers & The Party Line: Hootenanny, Anyone? |publisher=NPR |date=April 13, 2013 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

A ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]'' reviewer called Carnival an "Americana gem" writing that "the album never fades through 14 tracks, a testament to the songwriting and musical arrangements."<ref name="tampabay1"/>

The video for Struthers' song "Bike Ride" from the album ''Carnival'' debuted at No. 1 on [[Country Music Television]] Pure's 12-Pack Countdown in November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/bike-ride-debuts-at-1/ |title=Bike Ride Debuts at #1!!! |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=November 23, 2013 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>

==Discography==
;Studio albums
*''I Heard The Bluebirds Sing'', as Dirt Road Sweetheart, a duo with her father Alan Struthers (2008)
*''Nora Jane Struthers'' (2010)
*''Carnival'' (2013)
*''Wake'' (2015)
*''Champion'' (2017)
*''Bright Lights, Long Drives, First Words'' (2020)
*''Back To Cast Iron'' (2023)

;EPs
*''Country EP No. 1'' (2014)
